docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the second set of answers from Joshua B. Freeman, a historian and the author of "Working-Class New York: Life and Labor Since World War II."We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

headline.main: Answers About New York's Working Class, Part 2

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new polls shed light on the divisions among Americans wrestling with questions raised by efforts to overhaul the health care system.

headline.main: Americans Remain Divided Over Health Care Proposals, Polls Say

docs.abstract: Two new polls provide insight into public concerns about a health care overhaul.
docs.snippet: Two new polls provide insight into public concerns about a health care overhaul.

docs.lead_paragraph: A lot of people are expecting big changes soon in the health care system, according to a new poll. But they are in for a big disappointment.

headline.main: Public May Expect Health Care Changes Sooner Than Congress Is Planning

docs.abstract: The public may have unrealistic expectations of how soon health care changes will actually change anything.
docs.snippet: The public may have unrealistic expectations of how soon health care changes will actually change anything.

docs.lead_paragraph: With just $1, the city could reacquire Battery Park City from a state-run authority; and the development would become a part of Manhattan, to which it really belongs.

docs.lead_paragraph: American car buying has been guided by one grand philosophy: Which one do I want? But now, another question has begun to percolate: Do I need a car at all?

headline.seo: For Some, the Car Is No Longer a Must-Have

docs.lead_paragraph: MoveOn.org has created a new advertisement in support of the public insurance option that features the actress Heather Graham in running clothes, sprinting against overindulgent insurance company representatives. The advertisement will appear on national cable television and on the Internet, although the organization says it does not know yet in what markets.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are evenly divided on President Obama's plan to overhaul the health care system, according to the latest CNN/Opinion Research Corporation poll. But the latest USA Today/Gallup poll suggests that many people are reserving final judgment on the legislation in Congress until all the details have been ironed out. In the CNN poll, 49 percent favor Mr. Obama's plan to overhaul health care and 49 percent oppose it. But when asked whom they trust more to handle the changes, half of those surveyed named Mr. Obama, while a third said the Republicans in Congress.
docs.abstract: CNN/Opinion Research Corp poll finds that respondents are evenly divided on Pres Obama's plan to overhaul health care system, with 49 percent in favor and 49 percent opposed; USA Today/Gallup poll suggests that many people are reserving judgment on legislation until all details have been ironed out (S)
